isis.stitle: International® T 444E Diesel Engine - Model Years Late 1997 to 2003 - Crankcase, Crankshaft, Connecting Rods, And Pistons - Connecting Rods, Pistons and Piston Rings - Removal

caution.para: To avoid piston damage, if a carbon ridge is evident at the top of the cylinder bore, remove carbon ridge prior to removing the connecting rod and piston assemblies. This reduces the chance of piston ring land damage during removal.

step1.para: Use a razor knife or emery board to scrape carbon ridge from top of cylinder bore.

caution.para: For newer style connecting rods, keep the fractured mating surfaces clean and free of lint and debris. Do not allow the mating surfaces to rest on any surface. Do not bump the mating surfaces or drop the connecting rod or cap. This could cause chipping and wear on the mating surface, resulting in improper mating during installation and possible engine damage.

step1.para: Rotate crankshaft to position journals for removal of connecting rod assemblies.
Mark each connecting rod and its respective rod cap with the cylinder number before removing them from the engine. Also mark the rod caps for correct orientation to each rod.

caution.para: There are two style connecting rods being used:

item.para: Older style connecting rods use mounting nuts. The mounting nuts should turn freely off the connecting rod studs. If binding exists, check for bent or damaged threads to avoid engine damage.
Newer style connecting rods use self-retained bolts. Connecting rod bolts should turn freely. If binding exists, check thread condition carefully during inspection to avoid engine damage.

step1.para: Unscrew the two connecting rod mounting nuts or bolts. Remove the connecting rod cap.
Remove the piston and connecting rod assemblies from the crankcase as follows:

step2.para: Rotate the engine into a vertical position (front end up).

figure.caption: Installing the Connecting Rod Guide Protector Caps (Old Style Connecting Rod)

step2.para: Old style connecting rods: install aluminum connecting rod guide protector caps over the connecting rod studs to prevent damage to the crankshaft rod journals.

figure.caption: Pushing the Old Style Connecting Rod and Piston Out Of the Cylinder Bore
Pushing the New Style Connecting Rod and Piston Out Of the Cylinder Bore

step2.para: Use a wooden or plastic handle to push the connecting rod and piston assembly out of the cylinder bore.

figure.caption: Removing Old Style Piston and Connecting Rod Assembly from Crankcase
Removing Piston and Connecting Rod Assembly from Crankcase

step2.para: Once the piston rings are free of the cylinder bore, remove the assembly from the top of the crankcase.

step1.para: Mark each connecting rod and its respective bearing cap with the cylinder number from which they were removed.

caution.para: On engines using fractured connecting rods: DO NOT alter or damage the fractured mating surfaces of the connecting rod and cap.

figure.caption: Matching Cap and Connecting Rod Numbers

step1.para: Upon removal, make sure matching connecting rod and cap remain together as a set. A cap from one connecting rod is not interchangable with any other connecting rod.
